render.tex: %text \textcolor{blue}{\text{Product and Quotient Rule}} \[ \frac{d}{dx}\left[ f(x)\cdot g(x) \right] = ?\] and \[ \frac{d}{dx}\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = ?\] %

reason.tex:
%text Given two functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$, \underline\text{if their derivatives are defined}, then
% \begin{align} \frac{d}{dx}\left[ f(x)\cdot g(x) \right] &= f'(x)\cdot g(x) + f(x)\cdot g'(x) \\ \frac{d}{dx}\left[ \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\right] &= \underbrace{\dfrac{f'(x)\cdot g(x) - f(x)\cdot g'(x) }{g(x)^2}}_{g(x)\neq 0}\\ \text{where } f'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx}f(x) \\ \text{and } g'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} g(x) \end{align} %text
The first rule is called the \underline\text{Product Rule} or \underline\text{Leibniz's Rule}.
The second is called the \underline\text{Quotient Rule}. %
